she used y-y0 =v0t+1/2ayt^2 starting from 7:03, and she basically said that the initial position of the ball ,y0 is 1 m and the final position is 0 meaning the ball fell 1 meter ,the ball had no initial velocity so v0t becomes zero, ay, the acceleration in the y-direction is -9.81 m/s^2, and solving the equation as -1=0+1/2*9.81t^2 leads to -2 =9.81t^2, to -2/9.81=t^2, and taking the sqare root, the answer is t= 0.452 seconds, basically she plugged in variables into y-y0 =v0t+1/2ayt^2 and solved for time t.

1) Thank you for doing a physics CC.  2) Please emphasize quality over quantity.  It feels like you are trying to take the entire content from a 50 minute lecture from a traditional physics course and squish it all into a 10 minute video.  You will end up with better videos if you instead spend your 10 minutes on exploring one interesting idea/aspect of physics at a time.  Slow down and don't try to include everything.    3) One option: have some videos be conceptual videos where you present ideas, and other videos be application videos where you work out example problems.    4) You are going too fast with the math for me to follow you (and I'm a physics professor).  I can't read the equations and understand the commentary before it disappears.  So either I don't worry about understanding it or I have to pause/rewind the video (either way this means something is wrong with the video).  You need to make a difficult choice: either go conceptual and don't emphasize the math OR dedicate the time and screen space with the math so that people can follow you.  As it is, you are choosing the worst of both worlds by giving a mathematical presentation but not giving people enough time to absorb it.   5) Don't expect people to automatically memorize numbers.  For example at 5.05-5.10 in video #4, don't erase one line of math before presenting the second.  Let people see and appreciate the simplicity of adding vectors without needing to backtrack.  6) Thank you for doing a physics CC.

I think I figured out why Crash Course Physics doesn't work as well as the other CC's. The other CC's use humorous pop culture references to keep people engaged, and to help people understand the underlying concepts.   Unfortunately, pop culture references don't do a very good job of explaining equations. Math can really only be understood through practice. CC Physics lacks the humor, the relatable analogies, and the practice (i.e. homework) needed to be an effective teaching tool for people that haven't yet learned physics and calculus. For those viewers who think they have fully understood what vectors are (without having taken any advanced physics/math course) :  Τhere actually are some subtleties in the definition of a vector given in the video above, which could lead you to a much more rigorous definition. When you say "a vector is a quantity with magnitude and direction", or "a vector is a quantity with components (N components in an N-dimensional space)" you are not stating a very important property of a vector: The fact that if you change a coordinate system using a rotation, you know that the magnitude of the vector will stay the same.   From this fact you can find the exact transformation law of a vector under such a change of coordinate system. Using this logic you can generalize the notion of a vector in any physical theory, like for example the 4 dimensional spacetime of special relativity and the infinite dimensional space of wavefunctions in quantum mechanics.

i and j are used commonly, but when referring to graphical vectors, its much easier for begginers to read when in Cartesian vector form than using unit vector form. Mostly because you can switch the order of i and j (5j-2i for example, many beginners in vectors may confuse that for the vector <5,-2> when it really is <-2,5>) with cartesian vector form that mistake is much harder to make. Also its a good thing to get people used to very early because when you start to deal with 3D vectors and add in k. Thats when Cross Products and dot products come into play and using when ijk then you start making simple mistakes that you really shouldnt be.

Exactly, as an electrical engineer, i and j are both used as the imaginary number (i^2 = -1), which is used for example in eulers wave equation.   The problem is that when describing a number with both a real and imaginary part we denote it as a+i*b, where b is the imaginary part and a is the real part. One way to think of this is in a unit circle, where the imaginary part is along the y axis. This means that we can also write it in polar form. You probably know all of this, but the trouble here is that the use the SAME notation for describing the components of a real vector and a vector with an imaginary part, which is completely stupid. Insanely dumb. Therefore, we have always just called it x*a+y*b when describing something like a velocity vector. So much better!!  To summarize: You (crashcourse) are making it really hard for people when you get to imaginary numbers, stop that.

@onehair190  Note: In typing out my justification for this problem, I realized that I actually got the problem wrong, so I'll write this partly to explain how to solve this problem, and partly to correct my previous mistake.  For part a, we know that the initial velocity is 120 ft/sec, the initial position is 0 ft above the ground (we're just gonna assume that the ball was thrown straight up into the air so that there is only one dimension to contend with: the vertical axis), and the displacement (x - x initial) is 216 ft. We know that the displacement is 216 feet because x = 216 and x initial = 0, so 216 - 0 = 216 ft. We also take for granted that the acceleration of the ball is - 9.81 m/s^2, since gravity pulls the ball downwards as it flies upwards, but we have to convert it into ft/s^2, which is something I neglected to do when I first solved this problem (As an aside, screw the English measuring system. Why would we ever use the English system of measurement in any scientific discipline?) Plug all of these values into the displacement curve equation (x-x initial = v0*t + 1/2*a*t^2).  216 ft = (120 ft/sec)t + 1/2(-32.19ft/s^2)t^2  Now, we have to solve for t. This may seem like a dead end at first, but consider the fact that the ball will fly upwards, reach a certain point, then fall downwards. In other words, it will make a parabola (on the position/time graph, the real life ball will go up and down in a straight line because, as I said earlier, we're only working in one dimension), so the final equation must be a quadratic equation. Subtract the 216 ft from both sides, simplify, and you're left with  (-16.1 ft/s^2)t^2 + (120 ft/s)t - 216 ft = 0  Finally, when you put this information into the quadratic formula, you'll find that you have two valid answers: 3.04 seconds and 4.41 seconds. The first value tells you when the ball will reach 216 ft as it ascends, but the second value is just as correct as the first because it tells you when the ball will reach 216 ft as it descends. However, Cyberxxx cyberxxx was probably looking for the first value specifically.   To answer part b, we'll just take the information we have from part a and apply it again. When the ball reaches a velocity of 0 ft/s, it will stop ascending. Therefore, this could be considered the ball's maximum height (or local maximum for any calculus fans out there). If we know the ball's maximum height, we will automatically know whether or not the ball surpassed the 900 ft mark. We'll simply plug the values we need into the definition of acceleration equation ( v = v initial + at), and we get  0 ft/s = (120 ft/s) + (-32.19 ft/s^2)t  Solve for t, and we see that t = 3.73 seconds. Plug that into the displacement curve equation because we are trying to find the displacement of the ball at that time.  displacement = (120 ft/s)(3.73 s) + 1/2(-32.19 ft/s^2)(3.73 s)^2  After that, all you have to do is solve the equation, realize that x initial is still 0 ft, and conclude that the displacement is equal to the maximum height of the ball: about 224 ft. So the ball definitely isn't going to reach 900 ft.  Sorry that that was a really long explanation, but physics can get complicated and I wanted to make sure that you could understand each step in detail.

+CrashCourse There's a mistake with baseball example. When you throw the one ball horizontally it takes longer to hit the ground as you've now increased the distance the ball has to travel to hit the ground. As both balls are only falling due to gravity it would be impossible for them to both hit the ground at the same time.

+jpchevron You obviously don't understand the point of vectors. Gravity only affects the y component of the ball as it falls. Throwing the ball sideways doesn't make gravity weaker. The ball may travel a longer distance because its final position is offset by the x-component but it still hits the ground at the same time as the ball being dropped normally.

+jpchevron The vertical distance is the same for each object.  Each falls at the same rate with an acceleration of 9.8 m/s/s,   You can ignore the horizontal component of the motion for now,  Each ball falls with identical downward velocity and acceleration.  Each will take x seconds to hit the ground.  The only difference is that in these x seconds, one ball will have traveled in the horizon plane as well as the vertical.     The absolute velocity of the two balls is not the same, just the vertical.

+jpchevron To boil down what the other commentors were saying, you're basically conflating velocity and speed -- the magnitude of the velocity. I can understand why you wouldn't've recognized it, though, because you're getting into the true nuanced difference between the two, here. The ball that was thrown does have a longer distance to travel before it hits the ground, but its speed is also higher than the ball that was dropped. Also, the thrown ball's velocity vector is pointed in a different direction, a direction that causes its downward component to match the dropped ball's downward component. Thus, both balls are still falling at the same rate and hit the ground at the same time.

+jpchevron i want to try and explain the example given without using vectors explicitly, and do it twice, as i think that there is good reason to question the example without actual data.  firstly,  not only has the distance of the ball's path increased, but the initial velocity has increased, therefore it will travel further faster compared to the stationary starting ball, therefore the balls can hit the ground at the same time. (as motion is not linear, we cannot directly use the kinematic(linear motion) equations)  secondly, newton's second law states a body at rest or in motion at constant velocity in a straight line will stay at rest or in motion at constant velocity unless acted upon by an unbalanced force so, the horizontally moving ball should move horizontally, and the stationary ball should stay stationary. however, gravity is a thing, and it just so happens to be acting at full force upon the balls, causing acceleration = g, downwards. as the stationary ball accelerates downward, the distance between it and the ground decrease until it hits the ground. let's call the distance traveled, h, and the time it takes, t now, the horizontally moving ball will never hit the ground, nor run away from the ground unless a force acts. and gravity does act, moving the ball downward. as the initial movement isn't helping or hindering the ball getting to the ground, the ball still needs to cover distance h using acceleration g, and goodness!, that's time t. unless you fling the ball off a cliff, but then h is different, or if you through the ball downward, as then the ball will hit the ground without acceleration, or through it upward, so the distance covered will begin to increase  hope this helps, if the 21 lines or so of wibbly wobbly  doesn't make sense, come back after they go through Newton's Laws. between them, a=dv/dt, v=dx/dt, and the energy stuff, motion is covered. i understand why the math is so important, and why they are trying to cram secondary level math into the course, but i think that they can miss the beauty of a subject that flows naturally from these things.

+randomdogdog What some are saying about the horizontal speed making a distance in the time to reach the ground is technically true but for low velocities and short distances these effects are largely insignificant and it can be modelled as if it is just gravitational freefall with the ground as a flat surface. At high velocities or if the object travels a significant distance horizontally then you do need to start considering the fluid dynamics forces from the air interaction and also the centripetal forces needed to keep the object at a constant height above the curved surface of the real Earth or alternatively calculate the final position when it reaches the ground which if using 0m for the start point would be -(sqrt(d^2+r^2)-r)m which is pretty negligible for short distances, like -0.08m at 1km -0.31m at 2km etc.
